chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of infantile colic
chapter.summary: Covers the management of suspected infantile colic in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 6 months.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage infantile colic?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Reassure the parents/carers that infantile colic is a common problem that should resolve by 6 months of age.

  • Advise on sources of information and support, such as:
    • The NHS information leaflet Colic.
    • The BMJ Best Practice information leaflet Colic in babies.
    • The self-help support group Cry-sis for families with excessively crying or sleepless children, which has a website (available at www.cry-sis.org.uk) and runs a national telephone helpline (0845 122 8669).
    • The family's health visitor or nursery nurse.
  • Advise on strategies that may help to soothe a crying infant, such as:
    • Holding the baby through the crying episode.
    • Gentle motion (such as pushing the pram or rocking the crib).
    • 'White noise' (for example from a vacuum cleaner or hairdryer).
    • Bathing the infant in a warm bath.
    • Ensuring an optimal winding technique is used during and after feeds, if needed.
  • Encourage parents/carers to look after their own wellbeing by:
    • Asking family and friends for support, if possible.
    • Meeting other parents/carers with babies of the same age, to share experiences and access peer support.
    • Resting when the baby is asleep.
    • Putting the baby down in a safe place, such as their cot, if they feel unable to cope with the crying for a few minutes, to allow 'time out'.
  • If the mother is breastfeeding, encourage her to continue wherever possible.
    • If there are suspected breastfeeding problems, see the CKS topics on Breastfeeding problems and Mastitis and breast abscess for more information.
  • Do not recommend the following management strategies, as there is insufficient good-quality evidence for their use:
    • Simeticone (such as Infacol®) or lactase (such as Colief®) drops.
    • Maternal diet modification if breastfeeding, or changing the infant milk formula preparation.
    • Probiotic supplements.
    • Herbal supplements.
    • Manipulative strategies, such as spinal manipulation or cranial osteopathy.
  • Arrange for follow-up of the infant and family, depending on clinical judgement.
    • If symptoms are severe or persist after 4 months, consider an alternative underlying cause for symptoms.
  • Seek specialist advice from a paediatrician or arrange referral, depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • Parents/carers feel unable to cope with the infant's symptoms despite reassurance and advice in primary care.
    • The infant is not thriving, or symptoms are not starting to improve or are worsening after 4 months of age.
    • There is a suspected underlying cause for symptoms which cannot be managed in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of infantile colic are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Postnatal care: Routine postnatal care of women and their babies [NICE, 2015], two Cochrane systematic reviews Manipulative therapies for infantile colic (Review) [Dobson, 2012] and Pain-relieving agents for infantile colic (Review) [Biagioli, 2016], two further systematic reviews of treatments for infantile colic [Hall, 2012; Lucassen, 2015], and expert opinion in review articles on the management of infantile colic [DTB, 2013; Waddell, 2013; Akhnikh, 2014; Johnson, 2015], crying in infancy [McKenzie, 2013], and infant gastrointestinal symptoms [Vandenplas, 2015a].

Providing reassurance, sources of information, and self-help strategies
  • The recommendations on providing reassurance, accessing peer support, and holding the baby through the crying episode are based on expert opinion in the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2015].
  • The recommendations on possible soothing strategies and behavioural modification of the parent-infant interaction are based on expert opinion in review articles [DTB, 2013; McKenzie, 2013; Waddell, 2013].
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that providing effective coping strategies and methods to soothe the infant are essential to reduce parental stress and anxiety [DTB, 2013].
    • Behavioural modification may reduce colic symptoms, possibly by increasing maternal responsiveness and time spent with the infant [DTB, 2013].
Advice on continuing breastfeeding
  • This recommendation is based on a systematic review of multiple treatments for infantile colic [Lucassen, 2015], expert opinion in review articles [Akhnikh, 2014; Vandenplas, 2015a], and the fact that there is no known association between feeding method and the development of infantile colic [DTB, 2013].
Treatments not recommended
  • A systematic review of hydrolyzed, low-lactose, or soya-based milk preparations, hypoallergenic diet for breastfeeding mothers, cranial osteopathy and spinal manipulation, and probiotics found insufficient evidence from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to recommend their use, as they are of unknown clinical effectiveness [Lucassen, 2015]. This is supported by low-quality evidence in two Cochrane systematic reviews [Dobson, 2012; Biagioli, 2016] and by expert opinion in a review article which concludes there is little evidence to support the use of simeticone, lactase drops, and probiotics, and insufficient evidence to recommend complementary therapies such as herbal supplements and spinal manipulation [DTB, 2013].
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that there is inconsistent and conflicting evidence on the benefits of lactase drops for the treatment of infantile colic [DTB, 2013], and this is supported by a systematic review of medical therapies for infantile colic which found no evidence for benefit of the use of lactase drops [Hall, 2012].
    • Simeticone is theorized to reduce intraluminal gas in the infant gut, however a systematic review of two RCTs found conflicting results and no difference in the reduction of colic episodes compared with placebo [Hall, 2012]. This is supported by low-quality evidence in a Cochrane systematic review of three small studies comparing simeticone with placebo (one RCT and one meta-analysis of two cross-over studies). It found no difference in the reported duration of crying between the treatment and placebo groups, and the studies were at high risk of bias [Biagioli, 2016].
    • Expert opinion in a review article states that any maternal diet modification may result in improving symptoms of colic secondary to undiagnosed cows' milk protein allergy in the infant, rather than infantile colic with no underlying cause [DTB, 2013].
    • There is inconsistent and conflicting evidence on the use of probiotics for the treatment of infantile colic [Johnson, 2015; Vandenplas, 2015a]. A systematic review of five RCTs assessing probiotics in mainly breastfed infants found those receiving probiotics had a reduced crying time compared with controls, however it noted several possible confounders, two studies had an unclear or high risk of bias, and the results could not be extrapolated to predominantly formula-fed infants [Schreck Bird, 2016].
    • A Cochrane systematic review of pain-relieving agents for infantile colic found insufficient evidence to recommend herbal supplements as a treatment option [Biagioli, 2016]. In addition, expert opinion in a review article states that the use of herbal supplements has been associated with adverse effects such as vomiting, sleepiness, and constipation in the infant [DTB, 2013].
    • A Cochrane systematic review found insufficient evidence to support the use of spinal manipulation or cranial osteopathy, as the studies included were small, non-blinded, and at high risk of bias [Dobson, 2012].
Seeking specialist advice or arranging referral to a paediatrician
  • The recommendations on when to seek specialist advice or arrange referral are pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
